head.title: Patents; Plastic Wrap Allows Vegetables to 'Breathe'

hedline.hl1: Patents; Plastic Wrap Allows Vegetables to 'Breathe'

block.p: Researchers at Hercules Inc., a diversified manufacturing company in Wilmington, Del., obtained a patent this week on a "breathable" plastic wrap that they said could extend the shelf life of fresh fruits and vegetables.

The advantage of the new wrap is its ability to let air and carbon dioxide pass through without letting the fruits or vegetables dry out. "Certain fruits and vegetables respire, just like people," said David J. Hill, one of the inventors. "If you can control the amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide that's allowed in and out of the package, you can extend shelf life."

The advantage of the new wrap is its ability to let air and carbon dioxide pass through without letting the fruits or vegetables dry out. "Certain fruits and vegetables respire, just like people," said David J. Hill, one of the inventors. "If you can control the amount of oxygen and carbon dioxide that's allowed in and out of the package, you can extend shelf life."

The wrap is made from a polypropylene, a common plastic, but it has tiny particles of calcium carbonate that create microscopic pores when the plastic is formed into sheets. One important feature, Mr. Hill said, is that the pores and the airflow can be adjusted to suit the differing needs of different products.
Hercules has sold its product line based on the technology to Fresh Western Marketing Inc. of Salinas, Calif. Mr. Hill and Mitchell C. Antoon received patent 5,011,698.
